title.narrative: International Criminal Court - Trust fund for Victims 2019-2021
International Criminal Court - Trust fund for Victims 2019-2021

description.narrative:
Internationella Brottsmålsdomstolens fond för brottsoffer - ICC Trust Fund for Victims - har inkommit med en ansökan till Sida om treårigt bidrag till fonden 2019-2021. Den finansiella förfrågan till Sida är på 10 miljoner SEK per år, 30 miljoner SEK totalt.
Beloppsnivån följer samma nivå av årligt stöd som Sida har bidragit med sedan 2011 (förra perioden var 2016-2018) och som Sverige har bidragit med sedan 2006 (genom UD fram till 2011). Det totala finansiella behovet för fonden för 2019-2021 bedöms av dem själva till 24 miljoner Euro, så med andra ord täcker Sidas bidrag 12,5% av det totala behovet, eller en åttondel. Sverige har varit den största enskilda givaren till fonden sedan dess start, med totalt 25% av de totala frivilliga bidragen.
Den Internationella Brottsmålsdomstolen, ICC, instiftades genom Romstadgan (SÖ 2002:59, Romstadgan), 2002 som en permanent institution för lagföring av enskilda för de allvarligaste internationella brotten. Sverige har implementerat den genom en särskild lag (SFS 2014:406) om, straff för folkmord, brott mot mänskligheten och krigsförbrytelse. Parallellt etablerades också en specifik fond för offer för brott under ICC:s jurisdiktion - ICC Trust Fund for Victims. ICC undersöker och där det är berättigat åtalar individer misstänkta för de grövsta brotten mot det internationella samfundet; folkmord, krigsbrott, brott mot mänskligheten och militärt statligt våld som bryter mot FN-stadgarna. Fonden ger stöd och reparativ rättvisa till de offer som överlevt dessa brott, inklusive till deras familjer, i situationer och fall där domstolen har jurisdiktion.
Fondens primära mål är att stödja offren och deras familjer för att övervinna skada, leva ett värdigt liv och bidra till försoning och fredsbyggande i sina samhällen. TFV argumenterar också för offrens och deras familjer rättigheter i det globala rättssystemet och den humanitära sektorn.
Fonden har två mandat - reparativ rättvisa/ersättningar och assistans. Reparativ rättvisa har sin grund i ett domstolsbeslut och är därför strikt kopplade till ett visst brott och de angivna offren för det. Typ av kompensation kan också fastställas i beslutet. Assistansmandatet är mer flexibelt och används när ICC genomför utredningar eller när en rättegång pågår och kan därför hänvisa till ett bredare område eller ett helt land. Verksamheten inom assistansmandatet är fortfarande den största delen av fondens verksamhet, men ersättningsområdet ökar som en följd av de senaste avgjorda målen i domstolen (med högre transaktionskostnader involverade).
TFV har aktiviteter eller planer för aktiviteter i Uganda, DRC, Elfenbenskusten, CAR, Mali, Georgien och Kenya. Deras program expanderar på grund av utvidgningen av antal åtal inom ICC. Fondens ledning bedöms ha en stark kapacitet och består av människor som har arbetat där i mellan 5-10 år, med nära samspel och lyhördhet mot Sida och våra prioriteringar. Som sådan är TFV och dess organisation och aktiviteter välkända för Sida och vi har många bra resultat från detta långsiktiga samarbete.
Sida kommer under implementeringsfasen särskilt att följa uppTFV: s fortsatta förbättringar av resultatbaserad styrning, dess strategiska inriktning genom den strategiska planen, dess användning av sin egen riskmatris, jämställdhetskapacitet i fält och dess åtgärder för att ta hand om rekommendationerna från den senaste utvärderingen av fonden (genomförd av Independent Oversight Mechanism, ett kontrollinstitut för ICC).

The International Criminal Court's Trust Fund for Victims (ICC-TFV) has submitted an application to Sida of core support for 2019-2021, a three year programme. The financial request to Sida is 10 MSEK per year, 30 MSEK in total.
This follows the same level of annual core support that Sida has provided since 2011 (last period was 2016-2018) and Sweden has provided since 2006 (from the MFA until 2011). The total financial need for ICC-TFV during 2019-2021 amounts to 24 million Euro, i.e the request from Sida will cover 12,5% of the total need. Sweden has been the largest donor to the fund since its start in 2004, contributing with 25% of all voluntary contributions since.
The TFV and the ICC were both established pursuant to the Rome Statute from 2002. The ICC investigates and, where warranted, tries individuals charged with the gravest crimes of concern to the international community: genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity and the crime of aggression. The TFV provides support and reparations to the victims who have survived these crimes, as well as to their families, in situations and cases within the jurisdiction of the Court. The TFV’s primary goal is to support victims and their families to overcome harm, lead a dignified life and contribute towards reconciliation and peace building within their communities. The TFV also advocates for the rights of victims and their families in the global justice system and the humanitarian sector.
The fund has two mandates - reparations and assistance. Reparations have their basis in a court ruling and are therefore strictly linked to a certain crime and the specified victims of it. The type of compensation can also be laid out in the ruling. The assistance mandate is more flexible and is valid when the ICC are conducting investigations or when a trial is ongoing and can therefore refer to a wider area or a whole country. The activities within the assistance mandate are still the largest part of the fund’s activities but the reparations segment is increasing (with higher transaction costs to follow).
The TFV has activites, or plans for activities, in Uganda, DRC, Ivory Coast, CAR, Mali, Georgia and Kenya. Their programme is expanding due to the expansion of processes within the ICC. The TFV management has a strong capacity and consists of people who have worked there for between 5-10 years, with close interaction and responsiveness to Sida and our priorities. As such, the TFV and its organisation and activities are well known to Sida and we have many good results from this long-term cooperation.
Sida will during the implementation phase especially monitor the TFV's continued improvements on results-based management, its strategic direction through the strategic plan, its use of its own risk matrix, its gender equality capacity in the field and its actions to remedy the recommendations from the recent IOM evaluation of the fund.

Vision of the ICC-TFV:We envision a world where the rights of individuals are fulfilled and where survivors of the gravest human rights violations are empowered to live a life of hope, dignity and respect. Mission Statement:The TFV responds to the harm resulting from the crimes under the jurisdiction of the ICC by ensuring the rights of victims and their families through the provision of reparations and assistance. Strategic Goals:- Victims and their families overcome harm, lead a dignified life, and contribute towards reconciliation and peace-building within their communities.- The Trust Fund for Victims is a powerful advocate of the rights of victims and their families in the public domain, in particular the global justice system and humanitarian sector. Outcomes: - Repaired physical harm of victims and their families- Improved opportunities for victims and their families to improve their socio-economic status- Enhanced peace building and reconciliation among targeted population- Repaired psychological harm of victims and their families

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

description.narrative: IntroductionThe year 2019 was an important year of transition for the Trust Fund - from a lot of planning and preparations to implementation on a larger scale. New assistance programmes were initiated in DRC, CAR, and Côte d'Ivoire and the already ongoing programme in Uganda was renewed for another 5 years. Under the reparations mandate, activities were undertaken in relation to four proceedings: the Lubanga, Katanga, Al Mahdi and Ntaganda cases. The annual reporting for 2019 presents many relevant activities and even if it does not give much qualitative data and analysis, it manages to show that TFV's operations make a real difference for victims, their families and communities, for example through 'Resilient Survivor Stories' from project beneficiaries. The reporting also reflects attempts to achieve sustainability, for instance related to mental health at community level. For further details, see Dox 042746/20. Below are a few concrete examples of results achieved. It should be noted that during 2019, the TFV still operated under its old strategic plan which included four strategic goals. The new plan which was adopted in July 2020, only contains two strategic goals as seen in this Conclusion of Performance. The two goals that have been removed related to resource development and organisational performance. See also below under Dialogue issues. Examples of results - During 2019, 5 257 people directly benefited from the TFV assistance programme, including physical and psychological rehabilitation, and socio-economic activities. In addition, approximately 13 964 indirect beneficiaries, their families and communities were reached. - The TFV has implemented an assistance programme in Uganda since 2008 through which it has assisted more than 50 000 direct victims and over 275 000 indirect victims. In April 2019, a new 5-year assistance programme was launched in Uganda - in partnership with six implementing NGOs across the northern region that has been affected by the conflict between the government and the Lord's Resistance Army. - Related to physical rehabilitation, the programme trained final year students of the Orthopaedic Technology Training School in Mulago in prosthetic production. This facilitated the expansion of rehabilitation services that are relevant to victim situations and that is also sustainable by increasing local expertise in new technologies. In terms of psychological rehabilitation services, the TFV continued to use Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) to improve social functioning among conflicted affected communities.Through a daily mood scale, it has been indicated that a majority of beneficiaries of CBT have a 'good mood'. - In addition, Community Support Structures (CSS) have continued to play an important role in mediation of conflicts in their communities. The TFV reports that CSS have resolved 86 conflicts in the Agago district, including conflicts over land, domestic violence, and child abuse. - Related to reparations it can be mentioned that in March 2019, the Trial Chamber approved the implementation plan proposed by the TFV in the Al Mahdi case in Mali. Security concerns and restrictions in Northern Mali had made it necessary to develop alternative approaches for implementation of the proceedings.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
